head.title: Gays and the Boy Scouts: A Town's Responsibility

hedline.hl1: Gays and the Boy Scouts: A Town's Responsibility

abstract.p: Bruce G Brodsky letter on August 6 article holds Huntington and Smithtown, Long Island, should ban Boy Scout troops from using facilities because they refuse to admit gay scoutmasters (S)

block.p: Re: the struggle by the Huntington and Smithtown school boards over possibly banning Boy Scout troops from using their facilities because the Scouts will not accept gay scoutmasters [''Ruling Clouds Scouts' After-School Access,'' Aug. 6].
This issue goes far beyond the boards' particular problem.

Re: the struggle by the Huntington and Smithtown school boards over possibly banning Boy Scout troops from using their facilities because the Scouts will not accept gay scoutmasters [''Ruling Clouds Scouts' After-School Access,'' Aug. 6].
This issue goes far beyond the boards' particular problem.
We as a nation cannot continue to teach our children to be respectful of people who are different while supporting organizations that promote discrimination.

The Supreme Court may have agreed with the Boy Scouts' legal argument that private organizations are free to set their own standards for membership, but the court missed an opportunity to say that intolerance, prejudice and discrimination is always unacceptable.

Having risen to the position of junior assistant scoutmaster, I am distressed by having to encourage people to express their displeasure with the Boy Scouts' policies. But when hundreds of Eagle Scouts felt deeply enough about the issue to return their hard-earned badges, how can we sit and do nothing?
